quickScenarioChallenge.challengeSubtitle: Don't worry if you get it wrong‚Äîthat's how you learn!
quickScenarioChallenge.scenarioStory: Your software team is about to release version 1.0. Testing found: 15 critical bugs (system crashes), 42 major bugs (missing features), 120 minor bugs (UI glitches). Your release date is tomorrow. The sponsor asks: 'Can we release?' What's your recommendation?
quickScenarioChallenge.question: What's your first move BEFORE answering the sponsor?

options.A: Release as planned‚Äîall software has bugs
options.B: Review the quality standards defined in the project charter‚Äîcompare actual defects to acceptable thresholds
options.C: Fix the 15 critical bugs and release in 2 weeks
options.D: Delay 6 months to achieve zero bugs

insights.explanation: Quality means 'fitness for purpose'‚Äîmeeting defined standards, not perfection. Your team needs to know: What's acceptable? 5 critical bugs? 10? Zero?
insights.pmbokSupport: Quality is planned into the project from the start, not inspected in at the end

insights.explanation: If the standard says 'zero critical bugs before release,' then 15 critical bugs means NO RELEASE. If it says '‚â§20 critical bugs acceptable,' then it's a GO decision.
insights.pmbokSupport: Compare actual quality metrics to defined thresholds to make release decisions

insights.explanation: Releasing with known critical bugs = user risk. Delaying fixes = cost and schedule risk. Standards help balance this trade-off.
insights.pmbokSupport: Quality decisions involve trade-offs between cost, schedule, and risk

trapSection.explanation: Without defined standards, every release decision becomes a guessing game.

Assumes which bugs are acceptable without checking project standards

checklist: What quality standards were defined for this deliverable?
How do actual metrics compare to standards?
Is there a release gate/acceptance criteria document?
Who approves the trade-off (quality vs. schedule)?
patternRecognition.patternRule: Quality decisions require comparing actual metrics to defined standards, not gut feel. Standards = decision framework.

coreFramework.frameworkIntro: Quality management prevents defects and protects the project's value:

rows.action: Identify quality requirements and standards EARLY. What's acceptable? Create a quality management plan.
Define how to measure quality: defect count, test coverage %, performance benchmarks, user satisfaction.
Build quality INTO the process: code reviews, automated tests, design reviews, peer inspections. Prevention, not just detection.
keyQuestions: Are we preventing or just catching?

rows.action: Track all defects: severity, root cause, when discovered, effort to fix. Use data to improve.
keyQuestions: Could we have caught it earlier?
rows.examKeywords: Defect tracking, Root cause analysis, Lessons learned

rows.action: Test/inspect against standards. Quality control: compare actual to baseline. Flag what doesn't meet standard.
Compare actual metrics to defined thresholds. If within standard ‚Üí release. If not ‚Üí fix or escalate.
Document lessons learned: what quality metrics were achieved, what improved, what to change next time.
keyQuestions: How do we improve next project?
rows.examKeywords: Lessons learned, Historical data, Continuous improvement

pmbokConnection.quote: Quality is planned in, not inspected in. Define standards early and build prevention into processes

visualReferenceCard.quickReference: Quality = Fitness for Purpose (meeting standards) | QA = Building quality in (process) | QC = Finding quality (inspection) | Defect severity: Critical, Major, Minor | Standard first, then measure, then decide
visualReferenceCard.goldenRule: Standards define acceptable. Metrics measure. Decision gates compare metric to standard. No standard = no objective decision.
visualReferenceCard.examTip: Look for 'quality,' 'defect,' 'release,' 'standard' ‚Üí Identify what standard was defined. Compare metrics to standard. Make data-driven release decision.

secondScenario.scenarioStory: During planning, the team defined: 'Website release standard: maximum 3 critical bugs, maximum 20 major bugs, maximum 200 minor bugs.' Testing results: 2 critical, 18 major, 210 minor bugs. The PM proposes releasing. The QA lead says we should delay. Who's right?
secondScenario.question: What's the correct decision?

options.A: Release‚Äîwe're below the critical and major thresholds
options.B: Don't release‚Äîwe exceeded the minor bug threshold
options.C: Release the site; fix the minor bugs in next iteration
options.D: Escalate to sponsor with the data; let them decide the trade-off

quotes.text: Quality is not negotiable. But what IS negotiable is which bugs are acceptable. That decision must be made early, not during release.
quotes.author: Andrew Ramdayal

quotes.text: Quality is planned in, not inspected in. The cost of prevention is always less than the cost of fixing defects later.
quotes.author: PMI

fieldInsights.title: Standards Enable Decisions
fieldInsights.insight: Without pre-defined quality standards, every release decision becomes political. With standards, it's objective. Define thresholds in planning, not in crisis.

fieldInsights.title: QA Prevents, QC Detects
fieldInsights.insight: Quality Assurance = building quality in (process audits, code reviews). Quality Control = finding defects (testing). Both matter. QA is cheaper.

story.title: Quality Standards for a Safe Summit
story.narrative: A mountain expedition needs quality standards for safety. Before the climb, you define what's acceptable...

scenes.description: Before the climb: Equipment standards (rope tensile strength ‚â•10,000 lbs), oxygen purity ‚â•99.5%, guide certification, team fitness levels. Standards are set EARLY.
How do we measure quality? Check rope with tension gauge. Test oxygen purity with analyzer. Verify guide certifications. Define metrics upfront.
Build quality in: Pre-expedition training camps, equipment checks at Base Camp, daily rope inspections, guide briefings. Prevention prevents accidents.
Found a worn rope section? Log it. Climber feels dizzy? Log symptoms. Track near-misses. Root cause: why did rope wear? How prevent next time?
At Base Camp: Test all ropes, check oxygen levels, verify guide certifications. Every deliverable (rope, oxygen bottle) must pass inspection.
Rope: 10,000+ lbs tensile strength? Yes. Oxygen: 99.5%+ purity? 2 bottles failed. Threshold not met. Result: Don't use those bottles. Proceed with good equipment.
After summit: Document what standards worked, what failed, what changed. Use data for next expedition's standards.

story.moral: Quality management is like safety standards: **Q**uality planned early, **U**nderstand metrics, **A**ssure through process, **L**og defects, **I**nspect deliverables, **T**hreshold decision gate, **Y**ield lessons for improvement.
